Objection_letter3.objection7:
Equipment Breakdown Coverage;
The Department objects to including service contract coverages in an insurance policy, within the same policy document. Service
contracts are regulated under different laws under Title 20 regulations and require the obligor to obtain a permit to engage in the
service contract business. Additionally, a service contract requires a separate consideration from the one for an insurance contract.
There must be a clear distinction between the two types of coverage and how each affects consumers rights and obligations.
Pursuant to ARS 20-1095 et seq. an entity issuing service contracts needs to obtain a permit in order to do so. Issuing service
contracts without the appropriate registration constitutes an unlicensed activity and is prohibited by law.
Additionally, combining two disassociated coverages within the same policy without notice that the consumer is entering into two
separate coverage contracts causes consumer harm and confusion and is in violation of Arizonas Unfair Practices Act. See ARS 20-
443, 461. An insurance policy coverage is distinct and separate from the ones of a service contract and each can affect a consumers
rights and obligations differently.
In this case, Farmers Insurance Company of Arizona and Policy Form 93-7726 and any other forms that contain similar coverages,
does not comply with the statutory provisions cited above. The company does not hold a service company permit and is not
authorized to sell service contracts in Arizona. Furthermore, the current form filing includes both insurance coverage and service
contract coverage within the same form without any explanations or information relating to the differences between the two coverages
which will cause consumer confusion. Any claims under an insurance policy are treated differently from those under a service
contract and the implications for a consumer under each coverage are very distinct. Without clearly explaining the differences and
providing sufficient information to a consumer to make a well-informed decision, the current form language misrepresents pertinent
facts and insurance policy provisions relating to coverage.
The Department objects to the current form language. This filing will remain open until such time as this language is removed.  In
addition any related Rate or Rule filings will need to be revised or withdrawn. The Department welcomes scheduling a prompt

Objection_letter4.objection1:
Non-renewal Notice
Please update your notice to comply with following codes:
CIC §678(a)(1)(B)(iv) requires the NRN to include the Department’s Consumer Services Division contact information.
CIC § 678(e) requires the NRN to be accompanied by a notice that provides CDI’s California Homeowners Insurance Finder, online
tool, information and FAIR Plan information.
CIC §10095.7(b) – requires the insurer provide to applicant, or a policyholder whose policy is cancelled or nonrenewed, information

Objection_letter1.objection2:
Objection 2
          - Actuarial Justification (Supporting Document)
          Comments: "Provide a signed attestation by responsible personnel that the filing is compliant with the  following from Kansas
Statutes Chapter 40. Insurance : ""In determining whether rates are not excessive or inadequate or not unfairly discriminatory:
(a) Due consideration shall be given to:
(1) Past and prospective loss and expense experience within and outside the state;
(2) catastrophe hazards and contingencies;
(3) trends within and outside this state;
(4) loadings for leveling premium rates over time;
(5) dividends, savings or unabsorbed premium deposits allowed or returned by insurers to their policyholders, members, or
subscribers and the investment income of the insurer; and
(6) all other relevant factors within and outside the state, including the judgment of technical personnel.
(b) The expense provisions included in the rates to be used by an insurer may reflect the operating methods of the insurer, or group
of insurers, and, so far as it is credible, its own expense experience.
(c) Risks may be classified in any reasonable way for the establishment of rates and minimum premiums, except that no classification
may be based on race, color, creed or national origin and classifications in automobile insurance may not be based on physical
disability of an insured.  Rates thus produced may be modified for individual risks in accordance with rating plans, schedules,
individual risk premium modification plans and expense reduction plans that establish reasonable standards for measuring probable
variations in experience, hazards, expenses or any combination of those factors.
Such standards shall permit recognition of expected differences in loss or expense characteristics, and shall be designed so that
such plans are reasonable and equitable in their application, and are not unfairly discriminatory, violative of public policy or otherwise
contrary to the best interests of the people of this state. This section shall not prevent the development of new or innovative rating
methods which otherwise comply with this act.
(d) Rates may be modified for individual risks, upon written application of the insured, stating the insured's reasons therefore, filed
with and not disapproved by the commissioner within 10 days after filings.
(e) The rates may contain provisions for contingencies and an allowance permitting a reasonable profit.  In determining the
reasonableness of the profit, consideration shall be given to the investment income attributable to the line of insurance."

that addresses this reduction. If you have not submitted the filing, please do so as quickly as possible.

Objection_letter1.objection1:
Please respond to the objection below by Oct. 25, 2024.
     Objection 1
          Comments: Your 9-3-2024 Response Letter - Clarification
In your response to objection #1, you state, "Currently, we are providing coverage without requiring additional premium or a
declination of coverage. Providing coverage in this fashion is more beneficial to the policyholder than as required under MN Stat §
60A.0812...."
In your response to objection #2, however, you state: "By default, policyholders with the Family Protection Act Coverage will receive
the additional coverage afforded by the Family Protection Act, and the proposed premium charge of $1 reflects the cost of the
increase in coverage relative to the existing coverage."
I'm confused. Are you charging $1 for the watercraft liability coverage for family and household members? If you are charging $1 for
the coverage but not offering policyholders the opportunity to decline the coverage for the $1 reduction in premium?
Also, I see that your Family Protection Act form filing (# ALSE-134092062) does not include a declination form in compliance with
Minn. Stat. 60A.0812, subd. 6. As we explained in our 8-28-24 objection letter, you are required to offer policyholders the opportunity
to decline the coverage. Please submit a declination form or provide the SERFF tracking number of the filing that includes it.

Objection_letter2.objection1:
Objection 1
          - P & C Actuarial Memorandum and Data (Filings with a Rates component) (Supporting Document)
          Comments: NOTICE TO INSURERS PROVIDING BOAT/WATERCRAFT COVERAGE:
In your filing memo, you refer to November 1, 2023, "bulletin" addressing the requirements of the Family Protection Act. You state
that your program was compliant with the act because the memorandum stated, "Effective May 1, 2024, boat insurance policies may
not include a prohibited exclusion.
I call your attention to the several paragraphs following that statement that discuss the declination and premium reduction
requirements. You must allow applicants and renewing policyholders the opportunity to decline the coverage and reduce the
premiums of those that do so.
Objection_letter2.objection2:
Objection 2
          - P & C Actuarial Memorandum and Data (Filings with a Rates component) (Supporting Document)
          Comments: Clarification
You explain that you are already offering the coverage required by Minn. Stat. 60A.0812, the Family Protection Act, at no additional
cost to the policyholder. As I read the Family and Household Member Watercraft Liability table, you are now charging $1 to
policyholders who choose ("include") that coverage and not applying any increase or decrease to policyholders who opt out of
("exclude") the family and household member watercraft liability coverage.
The act specifically requires companies to offer a reduced premium to policyholders that decline the coverage. This rule does not
comply with the statute.
Please revise accordingly.

Objection_letter1.objection3:
Objection 3
          Comments: Re: Your 12-10-24 Response to Obj. 2 - Territory Rating
Thank you for the explanation regarding your use of "remainder."
Please note that the zip code rating statute was revised effective Aug. 1, 2024. The new language of Minn. Stat. 72A.20, subd. 13(b),
changes how companies can rate by zip code.
The subdivision states: "An insurer must not establish more than one geographical rating territory within the same city of the first
class or city of the second class that has 60,000 or more inhabitants. For purposes of compliance with this paragraph: (1) the
population of the cities subject to this paragraph is determined by the preceding United States decennial census, as reported by the
Minnesota State Demographic Center; and (2) the territorial boundaries of the cities subject to this paragraph are the boundaries as
the boundaries exist on December 31 in years ending in 0 or 5, whichever is more recent. Any revisions to the rating manual resulting
from a change in the territorial boundaries or population must be filed with the commissioner within 120 days of the date the data are
reported."
If the "remainder" zip codes are not part of a city with 60,000 or more residents, you are no longer required to rate them differently
from the area within the zip code that falls within city limits.
Please review your rating plan again to make sure it complies with the new language of Minn. Stat. 72A.20, subd. 13(b).

Objection_letter4.objection1:
Objection 1
          Comments: Your 7-17-24 Resp. to Obj. 4 - Zip Codes
Thank you for the explanation. As you move forward, please keep in mind that we cannot close your filing until this issue is resolved.
Note, too, that the Legislature revised Minn. Stat. 72A.20, subd. 13, in the last session. Effective Aug. 1, 2024, the statute will read, in
pertinent part:
"Subd. 13. Refusal to renew. (b) An insurer must not establish more than one geographical rating territory within the same city of the
first class or city of the second class that has 60,000 or more inhabitants. For purposes of compliance with this paragraph: (1) the
population of the cities subject to this paragraph is determined by the preceding United States decennial census, as reported by the
Minnesota State Demographic Center; and (2) the territorial boundaries of the cities subject to this paragraph are the boundaries as
the boundaries exist on December 31 in years ending in 0 or 5, whichever is more recent. Any revisions to the rating manual resulting
from a change in the territorial boundaries or population must be filed with the commissioner within 120 days of the date the data are
reported."
Again, the new language was effective Aug. 1. Because Minnesota is a "file and use" state for personal lines P&C rates, and because
your filing has an effective date of 3-1-24, the new language cannot apply to this filing. I bring it up as something for you to consider in
the future.

Objection_letter5.objection2:
Objection 2
          Comments: Re: Your 5-29-24 Response to Obj. 1 - Inspections
Page 6 of 29
You cite Minn. Stat. 60A.36, subd. 3, in your response. Homeowners policies fall under Minn. Stat. Ch. 65A. That said, I apologize for
my mistake. Under Minn. Stat. 65A.29, the company can cancel a homeowners policy "at any time during the first 59 days following
issuance of the coverage for any reason which is not specifically prohibited by statute." Under Minn. Stat. 65A.01, subd. 3c(a), "In the
event of a policy less than 60 days old that is declined, or a policy that it is being canceled for nonpayment of premium, the notice
must be mailed to the insured at least 20 days before the effective cancellation date. If a policy is being declined or canceled for
underwriting considerations, the insured must be informed of the source from which the information was received."
Please confirm that you will provide proper notice (20 days) of cancellation and that the cancellation notice will include the specific
reason for cancellation.

Objection_letter7.objection4:
Objection 4
          Comments: Loss History - Weather-related Claims
Page 7 of 28, Loss History
The second bullet states: "Two or more claims reported within three years."
Minnesota does not permit the use of claims based on weather events to surcharge a homeowners policy. Minnesota Statute
§65A.28, subd. 8 authorized the commissioner to promulgate rules to specify the grounds for nonrenewal, reduction in limits of
coverage or elimination of coverage. The rules must limit the grounds to specific factors, one of which is the insureds loss experience,
not to include natural causes.
Minnesota Rules Chapter 2880 were promulgated under this authority. Under these rules a transfer from one rating plan to another, if
the transfer results in a premium increase, is a nonrenewal. The rules set out specific conditions that, if met, would constitute
nonrenewal, including a surcharge to a premium for a condition that increases the potential for loss. By implication, where the
conditions are not met, the outcome would be inverted. That is, if the plan is transferred but there is no increase in premium, then a
nonrenewal has not occurred. Likewise, a surcharge applied for any reason other than a condition that increases the potential for loss
would be a nonrenewal.
The statutory and regulatory frameworks draw a distinction between natural causes and conditions. This distinction matters. As
discussed above, a surcharge based on a condition is specifically excluded from the nonrenewal definition in Minn. R. 2880.0100,
subp. 5. However, the next section of Chapter 2880 makes clear that the conditions in question are those that can be remediated by
the homeowner:
No insurer shall refuse to renew a policy of homeowners insurance unless based on one or more reasons which shall be limited to
the following  Refusal of the insured to eliminate known conditions which increase the potential for loss after notification by the insurer
that the condition must be removed. (Minn. R. 2880.0200(E))
Likewise, Chapter 2880 provides clarity on what constitutes natural causes that, per Minn. Stat. §65A.29, cannot provide the basis of
a nonrenewal decision. Minn. R. 2880.0200(G) states that losses caused by natural causes including but not limited to lightning, wind,
or hail cannot be counted as losses during the experience period for the purposes of nonrenewal. What emerges is a clear distinction
between those things in the control of the insured (conditions) and those not in the control of the insured (natural causes).

or bacteria. Additionally, if you choose to add the $50,000 of coverage, a rate must be added to the rating manual to provide an
increased limit option of $100,000, and the Landlord endorsement rule should be updated to reference this increased limit option.
8/12/2024 objection #1

apply up to at least $50,000 on an aggregate basis with optional increased limits up to at least $100,000. The Department notes the

for the increased liability limits. Please either amend the rate, rule, and/or form accordingly to comply with this requirement, explain
where the policy provides this coverage, or remove the exclusion for fungi from the Landlord endorsement.
Additionally, Rule G4. Landlord Policy Definition was updated on 3/1/24 to remove the reference to Additional Fungi, Wet or Dry Rot
or Bacteria Coverage. As this coverage should be available under the Landlord Policy, please revise the rule to add back the
reference to "Additional Fungi, Wet or Dry Rot or Bacteria Coverage".
9/25/2024 objection #1

added to the Landlord endorsement (LMHM 8342). Please note a revised Landlord endorsement was not included with the response.

Coverage C limit, which is a percentage of the Coverage A limit. Please note we asked that if the limit is the Coverage C limit that the
endorsement be revised because, as we previously mentioned, the endorsement currently states the limit is a percentage of
Coverage C (not Coverage A), which indicates the limit is less than Coverage C. For example, a similar World-Wide Coverage is

to the Coverage C limit). While it is not clear why the proposed endorsement would reference the limit as being a percentage of
Coverage C when the limit is the Coverage C limit, if you wish to refer to the percentage shown in the Declarations, then for the
reasons previously mentioned, the rate/rule manual must be updated as the limit cannot appear only in the Declarations (note the

acceptable:

the first sentence states "We will pay up to the Coverage C limit". With this option no updates need to be made to the rate/rule
manual.

this requirement, explain where the policy provides this coverage, or remove the exclusion for fungi from the Landlord endorsement.

or Bacteria Coverage. As this coverage should be available under the Landlord Policy, please revise the rule to add back the
reference to "Additional Fungi, Wet or Dry Rot or Bacteria Coverage".

          - Model Documentation (Supporting Document)
          Comments: (i) The company developed its indicated wildfire loss and LAE provision from the AAL output of the Verisk Wildfire
Model v3.2.1 with 100% credibility. One issue with the approach of applying AAL is that even if a few of the 100,000 simulated years
are extreme outliers, they could skew the mean far to the right and beyond any level of wildfire loss that could be reasonably
anticipated to occur in Nevada in the proximate future.
Has the company considered truncating the distribution of estimates from the simulation to eliminate extreme outliers that would skew
the mean in this way? If not, why not?
Furthermore, while the AAL itself may not incorporate a return-period assumption, the numerical value of the AAL will fall somewhere
between the numerical values for two return periods (X) and (X+1). What is the value of X?
(ii) The Division requests the company provide a list of all wildfire losses this book of business has experienced in Nevada in the past
10+ years, including the unadjusted total losses sustained on a yearly basis, wildfire loss ratio relativities, and any subrogation
received to offset the company losses.

IV. This calculation should show the AAL output of the Verisk Wildfire Model (adjusted to exclude non-renewing policies) and any
intermediary figures which are used to arrive at the final figure.

Objection 1
          - Third-party data information (Underwriting Guidelines) (Supporting Document)
          Comments: Please clarify if this program uses third party data in underwriting, including as a variable in tiering, classification, or
company placement.
Third-party data refers to any data not provided by the insured or determined by the insurer during underwriting.
If the company uses third-party data, please provide the information below. This information should be submitted in all underwriting
guideline filings for this program.
TAC 5.9342 (b)(3) (effective 1/8/24) requires that filings for programs that use third party models must include:
(A) the name of the data vendor or source;
(B) a description of the data, such as a data dictionary, that includes the name for each data element and the corresponding
definition;
(C) a description of how the data is used in underwriting; and
(D) a list of the underwriting guidelines that reflect use of the data;
For more information, please see the language at the link below.
https://www.tdi.texas.gov/rules/2023/documents/593101.pdf
Objection_letter1.objection2:
Objection 2
          - Third-party model information (Underwriting Guidelines) (Supporting Document)
          Comments: Please clarify if this program uses third party models in underwriting, including as a variable in tiering,
classification, or company placement. If so, please provide the information below. This information should be submitted in all
underwriting guideline filings for this program.
TAC 5.9342 (b)(4) (effective 1/8/24) requires that filings for programs that use third party models must include:
(A) the name of the model vendor or source;
(B) the model name and version number;
(C) a description of the model;
(D) a description of the model input;
(E) a description of how the model output is used in underwriting; and
(F) a list of the underwriting guidelines that depend on the output of the model.

Objection_letter2.objection1:
Objection 1
          - SPECIAL PROVISIONS - TEXAS, FMHO 6100TX , 09 24 (Form)
          Comments: Page 8, Section I - Conditions, C. Loss Settlement, d. the "replacement cost" at the time of loss
For replacement cost coverage of structures, the cost of replacement should not be determined at the time of loss.
Replacement cost coverage is conditioned on completion of repair or replacement, and it is intended to cover the insured for the
reasonable cost of that repair or replacement.
The cost of repair or replacement often changes before repair or replacement can actually be completed.  For example, the price of
materials and labor often tends to increase in the aftermath of a large event.
Please remove "at the time of loss" for consistency.

The insured is responsible for providing the itemization in b.(1) and might not be aware of everything that needs to be itemized. Either
remove this sentence of explain the purpose of this language and how it is fair. (Insurance Code 2301.001)

Objection_letter6.objection3:
Objection 3
          - SPECIAL PROVISIONS - TEXAS, HM 8100TX , 10 24 (Form)
          Comments: Page 2, Section 1 - Property Coverages, Building Property Losses We Do Not Cover, Item 21, Cosmetic Loss or
Damage, "This exclusion applies so long as the exterior surface materials and related components maintains its function as the
intended barrier protecting against exposure to the elements and leaking of water through the exterior surface materials."
As part of managements position on cosmetic damage exclusions, it was determined that the form must include language indicating
that coverage is provided if the damage reduces the expected functional life of the surface either immediately or over time. Damage

Objection_letter1.objection4:

          - Virginia Homeowners Tiering Manual, null (Rate)
          Comments: Coverage A per Square Foot:

Information" since the information can be provided by the insured or determined by the company in some other way.
Credit Based Insurance Score - Page T-10:
Per § 38.2-2126.C, "No Hit, Thin File, and No Information" each require actuarial justification for charging a non-neutral rate.
The Bureau would not consider "System Unavailable" an actuarially justified class of risk, but rather an uncontrollable and random
assignment. Remove the option.
The company must define what is meant by "Fat File" and "Not Assigned." If either of these classifications would not represent an
actuarially justified class of risk, the company should remove them from the table.
The company should clarify under what circumstances an insured would be able to refuse providing their credit score, since it is
derived from a third party.

The Bureaus position is that the mandatory offer of coverage for loss caused or resulting from water that backs up through
sewers/drains (§ 38.2-2120) is open-ended, which means that the company must honor requests to add the coverage when a
policyholder requests it. Therefore, insurers cannot refuse to add the coverage mid-term or impose a waiting period unless a loss-

          Comments: 1. We are still concerned with the existence of two sets of rates shown in your rate pages for HO-2 Homeowners
and Landlords Rental Dwelling. We do not follow how having separate base rates and curves successfully merges your dwelling fire
policies from before 6/30/2004 into your homeowners program.

why are the rates different? Is the coverage for Landlords Rental Dwelling the same as Landlords Rental Dwelling (former Dwelling

possibility for unfair discrimination, in violation of RCW 48.18.480 and 48.19.020, due to the potential for similar risks to receive
different rates. Please provide additional background information on these groups of policies and explain why you believe your rating
plan structure should not be considered unfairly discriminatory.

Objection_letter2.objection1:
The West Virginia Office of the Insurance Commissioner takes the following position regarding installment fees:
          *  The maximum installment amount allowed on personal lines policies is $3.00.

Please update the installment fee to the correct amount for personal lines.
